column3: str
<Sheet(ContentFinderCondition,IntegerParameter(1),3)/>

<Split(<Highlight>ObjectParameter(1)</Highlight>, ,1)/>! My, my, that I should find you here of all places. Though I suppose that's only right, considering I followed you. My well of inspiration has run dry, you see, and it is my hope that a change of scenery might offer the impetus my work requires.
And time again you have proven a knack for finding fascinating locales, with equally fascinating stories unfolding soon after.
When such a tale finally <Emphasis>does</Emphasis> unfold, I should very much like to hear it.
If you've no epic tales to share, perhaps I can regale you with a story of my own.
What will you do?
Ask to hear a story.
Nothing.
What will you ask about?
The holy blade, Save the Queen.
Battle fought in the mind of a dear companion? How thrilling, how compelling! Please, tell me more.
A specter of the late Emperor Varis. I suppose even a figment of one's memory, assuming sufficient creative liberties are taken, can prove as fearsome as a man of flesh and blood.
Admittedly, I cannot claim to have witnessed his prowess firsthand, but who has not heard tales of his savagery, his unparalleled might?
Yes, I do believe inspiration has struck, my friend. The brutal battle of words which proceeded a nightmarish clash 'twixt the Emperor and the realm's great liberator.
“You would dare approach me thus?” Lord Varis scoffed. “Where men of greater strength and mind both would flee, you dare commit to such folly?”
To which the liberator coolly replied, “How else am I to smite thee save...erm...approaching...”
An admirable attempt, if I were still learning my letters perhaps. It seems my prose yet wants for inspiration.
Might you humor me with a more detailed account of your confrontation? I require a more vivid picture if I am to do justice to your deeds.
Idols earned in Memoria Misera (Extreme) can be exchanged for gear and other items by speaking with C'intana in Revenant's Toll.
Gunnhildr's Blades were possessed of not one but myriad weapons with which they saved their queen. Oh, to see the look on the resistance soldiers' faces when Gerolt's work is complete.

Wait. Save the Queen? Why do those words sound so familiar... Yes, of course! Queen Gunnhildr was said to wield a holy blade bearing that name. A rather nonsensical moniker, if I may be so bold, but perhaps in ancient tongues it held some sense of grandeur.
That Bozjans still speak of her reign with such reverence is testament to their storytelling traditions. Traditions which may very well serve to rekindle the flames of this playwright's spirit.

Which is to say, there is little I know of the blade save for its name. When I at last find time to sit down and learn all there is to know of the queen and her gallant guard, I shall regale you with a tale unlike any you have heard before.
